Bachelor of Software Engineering | Bachelor of Software Engineering

- Title: Game Programming
- Code: CNTT11111
- Credits: 3 (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
- Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
- Lecture: 35 hrs
- Exercises on class: 10 hrs
- Self-study: 90 hrs.
- Parallel course(s): None
- Prerequisite course(s): None
- Faculty conducting the course:
- Information Technology, R1310, 13th flr., Building A1, The National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong Road, Hai Ba Trung District, Hanoi, Vietnam.
- Lecturers:
- MSc. Cao Thị Thu Hương, Tel: 0912916316  Email: huongct@neu.edu.vn
- MSc. Nguyễn Quỳnh Mai  Tel: 0983151792  Email: mainq@neu.edu.vn
- Kind of the course:

Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental □ | Fundamental □
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective □
* Meeting hour:

The course will equip students with basic knowledge of game programming. Students will be introduced to the game development process, the basic components of a game and game design, as well as basic knowledge about game engines. The course mainly introduces Unity software, basic components of Unity and programming methods with C# code to program a 2D and 3D game. The course also equips skills for teamwork, designing and deploying simple applications, compiling and running on devices; Reading and searching skills in English.

Text Book(s):
[1] Jared, H. (2019). Developing 2D Games with Unity: Independent Game Programming with C#. USA: Apress.
[2] Blackman, S. (2019). Beginning 3D Game Developtment with Unity. USA: Apress.
Others:
[3] Alan, T. (2019). Learn Unity for 2D Game Developtment. USA: Press.
[4] Thorn, A. (2018). Pro Unity Game Development with C#. USA: Apress
Software: Visual Studio Code, Unity, …

Table 4. Course goals
Goals | Goals Description | PLOs | Proficiency scale
G1 | The course provides in-depth knowledge of game development process, the basic components of a game and game design, as well as basic knowledge about game engines; Unity software, basic components of Unity and programming methods with C# code to program a 2D and 3D game. | PLO1.3 PLO1.4 PLO1.5 | 4
G2 | Learning to practice thinking skills, problem solving and good practice skills to game programming. | PLO2.2 | 4U
G3 | The course contributes to the development of the ability to work independently or in a team, to properly understand the responsibility of job performance and professional ethics. | PLO3.1 PLO 3.4 | 4, 4, 4

Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)

G1 | CLO1.1 | Understand the components of Unity Game processing | ITU4
G1 | CLO1.2 | Understand the process of building a Unity Game | ITU4

G2 | CLO2.2 | Skills in searching, evaluating and synthesizing documents on the internet and forums | TU4

G3 | CLO3.3 | Proper understanding of responsibility in job performance, professional ethics in work related to game programming. | U4

chunks.text:
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
chunks.breadcrumbs: 9. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION > 9.2. Requirements for attending classes

chunks.text:
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

9. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION
9.1. Requirements for taking final /terminal exams
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
9.2. Requirements for attending classes
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
9.3. Requirements for in-class behaviour
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
